Drug: Buprenorphine | cid: 644073
Source: erowid | Source description: Information about Buprenorphine (Temgesic, Subutex) including uses, images, and links to other resources.
Erowid name: buprenorphine
Category: PHARMS
Field: MainPage

                    Text: 
                    Buprenorphine



COMMON & BRAND NAMES

Temgesic; Subutex; Buprenex; Suboxone

EFFECTS CLASSIFICATION

Opioid; Analgesic; Anxiolytic

CHEMICAL NAME

17-(cyclopropylmethyl)-alpha-(1,1-dimethylethyl)-4,5-epoxy- 18,19-dihydro-3-hydroxy-6-methoxy-alpha-methyl-6,14- ethenomorphinan-7-methanol

DESCRIPTION

Buprenorphine is a semi-synthetic opioid derived from thebaine. It is an analgesic (pain killer) and has gained a great deal of notoriety for its ability to interrupt severe opiate addiction, including heroin and methadone addictions. It was approved by the FDA in 2002 for use as an opiate addiction treatment.

BASICS

EFFECTS

IMAGES

HEALTH

LAW

DOSE

CHEMISTRY

GENERAL INFORMATION #

Buprenorphine Approved by FDA October 8, 2002

Bits & Pieces of Information about Buprenorphine

Buprenorphine & Drug Tests

RELATED VAULTS #

Opiates

Naloxone

RESEARCH & JOURNAL ARTICLES #

An unusual case of death probably triggered by the association of buprenorphine [...] (2015)


                    Context: 
                    This section provides key information about buprenorphine, a semi-synthetic opioid used for pain relief and the treatment of opioid addiction. It details brand names, chemical classification, description, FDA approval, related substances, and links to further research, situating buprenorphine within Erowid's comprehensive index of pharmaceuticals, addiction treatments, and psychoactive substances.

It provides links related to buprenorphine and drug testing, connects users to related substances (opiate and naloxone vaults), lists select research articles, user experience reports, and curated off-site resources including primary, secondary, and addiction treatment information. It sits within the comprehensive overview of buprenorphine’s effects, use, health, law, and chemistry.

MEDIA COVERAGE #

The New York Times is dead wrong about drug addiction - Dec 22, 2013, salon.com

Addiction Treatment With a Dark Side - Nov 16, 2013, NYTimes

New drug treats the new face of addiction - USA Today, Jan 24 2006


                    Context: 
                    This section provides external links to news articles, official statements, and resources focused on addiction treatment and media coverage related to buprenorphine, following the main informational content about the drug’s uses, effects, and history. It highlights both medical and public discourse surrounding buprenorphine’s role in opioid addiction treatment.
